(d) LSV plots before and after 5000 cycles in O2-saturated electrolyte, rotating speed: 1600 rpm. Fig. 3 (a) Linear scaling relation between the adsorption energy of O* and OH*. (b) Linear scaling relation between the adsorption energy of O* and OOH*. (c) Linear relation between the activation barrier of O2 dissociation and the adsorption energy of O*. (f) Free energy diagram for Pt(111) and Co@CNB_l at 0 and 0.8 V vs RHE. Fig. 4 The projected DOS of C and O in Co@CNB_h (a), CNT (b), Co@CNB_l (c) and Gr (d). Graphical abstract One-dimensional (1D) metal-organic nanostructures hold great promise for preparing various 1D carbon/metal derivatives toward various electrocatalysis including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR); but it is challenging to synthesize them. Herein, 1D cobalt(Co)-metal-organic nanowires are prepared using the complex of Co2+ and 1, 2, 4-triazole. Direct carbonization of the as-prepared nanowires affords a well-defined structure of Co nanoparticles encapsulated inside the bamboo-liked 1D carbon nanostructure, i.e., carbon nanobamboos (Co@CNB). Owing to the outstanding electronic transport in bamboo-liked carbon structure, strong electronic coupling between the N-doped carbon and Co nanoparticles, the Co@CNB catalyst exhibits an excellent ORR performance comparable to the commercial Pt/C in alkaline solution. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the Co@CNB can strengthen the adsorption of all adsorbates (O*, OH* and OOH*) compared with a carbon nanotube, benifical for oxygen protonation and thus enhancing the ORR activity. Moreover, it is possible to outperform Pt intrinsically if the curvature of carbon shell is high enough in Co@CNB. Lastly, the zinc-air battery (ZAB) fabricated with Co@CNB as the cathode catalyst shows a higher peak power density and better cycling durability than those of the ZAB with Pt/C; suggesting the great potential of Co@CNB as efficient electrocatalysts for metal-air batteries. Keywords Metal-organic nanowires Carbon nanobamboos Oxygen reduction catalyst DFT 1 Introduction The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) proceed with a four-electrons transfer route plays an indispensable role in many electrochemical conversion devices, such as polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal-air batteries [1–3]. In order to accelerate the four-electron transfer process, platinum (Pt)-based catalysts have been studied for decades and verified to be the most effective catalysts for ORR [4–8]. However, the low earth abundance and high price of Pt greatly limits its potential for large-scale implementation. This dilemma has been a continued driving force for researchers to discover other scalable and cost-effective alternatives to Pt for high-performance ORR, especially nonprecious catalysts [9–13]. To this end, nonprecious transition metals (e.g., Co, Ni, and Fe.) coupled with carbons have attracted much attention [14–18]. Such focuses are originated from the fact that controllable and rational design of the architecture for metal/carbon catalysts (MCCs) enables the tuning of ORR performance. It’s well-known that the perfect crystal structure and outstanding chemical stability of carbons make them ideal supports to anchor the metallic nanoparticles (MNPs), thus improve the stability of MNPs during electrocatalysis [19–23]. Therefore, carbon supports such as multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), graphene and carbon black have been extensively studied. Particularly, the MWCNTs owning large surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, and superior electrochemical stability, have been demonstrated to be promising catalysts for ORR either with or without MCCs [24–25]. To enrich the active sites of MCCs for ORR, modifications of the carbon supports are widely employed, e.g., nitrogen (N) doping [26–30]. Pioneer studies conclude that N-doping decreases the band gap and then increases the electrical conductivity, which in turn enhances the ORR performance [31,32]. These advances inspire us to develop a new and simple approach to prepare novel nonprecious metal catalyst supported on 1D N-doped carbon for efficient ORR. Recently, metal-organic structures (MOSs) such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which is composed of metal ions/clusters and organic linkers, serve as a promising precursor for the fabrication of MCCs for various electrochemical reactions [33–35]. Among them, Co-based MOF, i.e., ZIF-67 has been frequently investigated due to its simple preparation and wide availability [36–39]. In contrast, the synthesis of Co-MOF with other morphologies such as nanowires (NWs) are rarely reported and let alone its derivatives. Compared to its 0D counterpart, 1D nanostructure forms film with better conductivity due to percolation network formed in the film. On the other hand, 1D nanostructure has much higher surface area than its 3D counterpart. Despite these advantages of 1D MOSs nanostructure, there is a lack of a simple approach for one-step synthesis of high-quality Co-MOSs NWs, because the growth of 1D nanostructure is more difficult to control than its 0D or 3D counterparts, due to the specific complex structure between metal ions and the organic linkers. Herein, we have successfully prepared a one-dimensional cobalt(Co)-metal-organic nanowires (Co-MONs) by simply mixing cobalt nitrate and 1, 2, 4-triazole (TA) in aqueous solution followed by a hydrothermal treatment. In our attempt, TA has been used as the organic linker because TA with three nitrogen atoms not only offers multiple chelating sites but also provides high content of nitrogen sources. Thereafter, the Co-MONs are pyrolyzed under argon atmosphere. As a result, the Co-MONs are transformed into carbon nanobamboos with encapsulated Co nanoparticles (Co@CNB). The as-prepared Co@CNB shows ORR activity better than commercial Pt/C, which demonstrates its great potential for energy conversion and storage. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were bought from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received without any purifications. Commercial Pt/C catalyst (20 wt%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Deionized water has been used throughout the whole experiments. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis Synthesis of Co-MONs: 3.4 g of 1, 2, 4-triazole was dissolved into 60 mL of water under stirring. Then 10 mL of of aqueaous Co(NO3)2 (0.8 mol L−1) solution was added and stirred for 5 min. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to a teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 100 mL, sealed and maintained at 180 °C for 20 h. After cooled to the room temperature, the product was collected with centrifugation and washed with water for several times. This synthetic method cannot be extended to synthesize the Ni-MONs. The final samples were obtained via freeze drying. Note that the normal heating drying approach led to an aggregation of the structure. Carbonization of Co-MONs: The dried MON sample was put in a crucible and then tansferred to the tube furnace. The heating process was carried out under Ar atomsphere with a flow rate of 50 sccm. The sample was firstly heated to 300 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1. After 2 h, the sample was climbed to the designated temperatures (T = 600, 700, 800, 900 and 1000 °C) at a rate of 5 °C min−1 and maintained for 2 h. Finally, the sample was cooled naturally and collected for further use. The chemical formula of the Co-MONs was determined to be Co1C4H4N6. The stoichiometric ratio between metal ion and deprotonated ligand is 1 : 2, namely Co1(deprotonated 1, 2, 4-triazole)2. The synthetic yield was determined to be 91% in terms of the Co precursor. 2.3 Instruments SEM images and the corresponding element mapping were obtained using a JEOL 7600F instrument. XRD patterns were used for phase characterization by Panalytical X’Pert Pro. TEM images and corresponding element mapping were obtained by FEI, United States, and JEOL-2010HR, Japan. The elemental analysis was conducted with a elementar vario EL III. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed temperatures ranging between 30 and 950 °C and at a heating rate of 10 °C min with N2 flow. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were collected at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) using automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (Belsorp-max) after degassing at 60 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) data were recorded on Kratos AXIS Supra. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Preparation of the catalysts inks: The as-prepared catalysts and commercial Pt/C was ultrasonically dispersed into a mixture containg water, ethanol and nafion (5% wt) with a volume ratio of 15 : 4 : 1. ORR tests: A three-electrodes system was used, which including a rotating disk electrode (RDE, 5 mm diameter), graphite rod and KCl saturated Ag/AgCl electrode was the working electrodes, counter electrode and reference electrode repsectively. The RDE was carefully polished with Al2O3 slurry and washed clean before use. Then certain amount of the catalysts inks was dropped onto the RDE with a pipett. The loading mass of the as-prepared catalysts and commercial Pt/C was 509 and 152 µg cm−2 repsectively. The electrochemical measurements were carried out with a Gamry Reference 600. All of the potentials used were converted to RHE (Reversible Hydrogen Electrode) via the following equation: E RHE = E Ag / A g C l + 0.059 × p H + 0.198 The ORR electron transfer number has been calculated according to the Koutecky-Levich equations: 1 j = 1 j k + 1 B ω 0.5 B = 0.2 n F ( D 0 ) 2 / 3 ν - 1 / 6 C 0 In the equation, j is the measured current density, jk is the kinetic-limiting current density, ω is the electrode rotation rate (rpm), n is the electron transfer number, F represents the faraday constant (96485C mol L−1). D0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (1.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1). ν is the viscosity of the electrolyte (0.01 cm2 s−1). C0 is the O2 concentration in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (1.2 × 10−6 mol cm−3). Zn-air battery: The Zn-air battery was assembled with a home-made cell. The cathode electrode which containing a current collector (nickel foam), a gas diffusion layer and a carbon paper was prepared through a hot-press method. Then, the catalyst inks were drop casted to the the carbon paper (1 mg cm−2) and dried naturally. For comparison, the cathode with commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.5 mg cm−2) was also prepared. A piece of zinc foil was polished sandpaper carefully, and then used as the anode. The electrolyte was consisted of KOH (6 mol L−1) and Zn(Ac)2 (0.20 mol L−1). Measurements were performed on a Gamry Reference 600. 2.5 Computational method Density functional theory (DFT) calculations for oxygen reduction reaction were conducted over Co@carbon nanobamboos (Co@CNB) and several other nanostructures, including carbon nanotubes (CNT), N doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) and graphene (Gr). Considering the effect of carbon wall curvature for nanobamboos, two different structures were applied for Co@CNB, constructed by Co nanoparticle (Co11) with N doped carbon nanotubes (high curvature, Co@CNB_h) or N doped graphene (low curvature, Co@CNB_l). The pyrrolic N (Npy-5) and pyridinic N (Npy-6) at the edge were also considered (Fig. S19). All the DFT calculations were carried out using the revised Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (rPBE) functional [40] through the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [41,42]. The Projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [43,44] was performed as the basis set with a cut-off energy of 400 eV. Single-wall carbon nanotubes, namely (6, 6) CNT, with 144 carbon atoms were modelled for all nanotube structures including 12 Å vacuum space over the wall. A Monkhorst-Pack k-point of 1 × 1 × 1 was applied for all CNT models due to the large size of the system. A p(6 × 6) single-layer graphene was applied with a Monkhorst-Pack k-point of 2 × 2 × 1 including 12 Å vacuum space. In addition, ORR over Pt(111) was also calculated as a reference applying a p(2 × 2) supercell with four layers, where two layers were fixed at the bottom. A Monkhorst-Pack k-point of 4 × 4 × 1 was applied with the vacuum space of 15 Å. The convergence of force was set to 0.05 eV·Å−1 for all the calculations, including structure optimizations and the locating of transition states, where the constrained optimization were applied [45]. The free energy corrections were conducted for all the adsorbates and gas molecules. A standard correction was applied, including zero-point energy, pressure, inner energy and entropy, following the equation: (1) E cor = E cor ZPE + E cor U + E cor P + E cor S where E cor ZPE refers to the correction of zero-point energy, E cor U and E cor P refer to the correction of temperature (inner energy correction) and pressure and E cor S refers to the correction of entropy. The free energy correction for entropy can be separated to transitional entropy, rotational entropy and vibrational entropy, where only vibrational entropy will be considered for adsorbates on the surface, which is only depended by the vibrational frequency [46]. The free energy corrections were conducted for all the adsorbates at 298 K with the pressure of H2 and H2O of 1.0 and 0.035 bar respectively. The free energy of O2(g) was calculated as: (2) G O 2 ( g ) = 1.23 e V × 4 + 2 G H 2 O ( l ) - 2 G H 2 ( g ) The chemical potential of OH– was calculated as: (3) G OH - = G H 2 O ( l ) - G H + In equilibrium, the chemical potential of a pair of (H+ + e-) at 0 V vs. RHE was referred to ½ chemical potential of H2 molecule in light of the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) approximation [47]. In addition, the solvation effect was considered especially on adsorbed OH* and OOH* due to the formation of H-bonds. Stronger adsorption energies was performed in previous studies by a value 0.30 eV [48], which is also applied in this work. Two different reaction mechanisms were investigated for electrocatalytic ORR including the dissociative (R3 + R4 + R5) and associative (R1 + R2 + R3 + R4, namely 4e- transfer steps) ones, according to the competition of O2 consumption from either direct dissociation (R5) or protonation (R1). Therefore, all the elementary steps can be summarized considering the alkaline environment: (R1) O2(g) + H2O(l) + e- + * ↔ OOH* + OH– (R2) OOH* + e- ↔ O* + OH– (R3) O* + H2O(l) + e- ↔ OH* + OH– (R4) OH* + e- ↔ * + OH– (R5) O2(g) + 2* ↔ 2O* Accordingly, three adsorbates (O*, OH* and OOH*) were focused in this work, and the adsorption energies (GO*, GOH* and GOOH*) were calculated referenced to the gas phase energies of H2O and H2. Hereafter, the reaction free energies of all elementary steps at 0 V vs RHE can be calculated: (4) Δ G R 1 = G OOH ∗ - 4.92 (5) Δ G R 2 = G O ∗ - G OOH ∗ (6) Δ G R 3 = G OH ∗ - G O ∗ (7) Δ G R 4 = - G OH ∗ (8) Δ G R 5 = 2 G O ∗ - 4.92 Additionally, the reaction free energy for electrochemal steps (R1 – R4) was highly affected by the electrode potential. The potential dependent reaction free energy can be calculated due to the CHE approximation: (9) Δ G U = G U 0 + e ( U - U 0 ) where U and U0 refer to the considered electrode potential U and 0 V vs RHE, respectively. The reaction free energy of thermochemial O2 direct dissociation (R5) was considered to be potential independent [49]. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis process of Co@CNB is illustrated in Scheme 1 . The Co2+ ions were connected with the TA linkers to form a NWs structure during the hydrothermal reaction (see experimental section for details). The as-prepared Co-MONs are yellow in color (Fig. S1). The weight percentage of the C, H and N element were determined to be 25.58, 2.126 and 42.685%, respectively, by the elemental analysis results. It is worth noting that the synthesis process of Co-MONs can be easily scaled up. The NWs structure of the Co-MONs was confirmed by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) in Fig. S2. The NWs have an average diameter of ca. 60 nm and length of several tens of microns. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of the Co-MONs (Fig. S3) showed a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 42.8 m2 g−1 with rare micropores. Similar results have also been reported earlier [50]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (Fig. S4) shows the crystalline nature of Co-MONs. The resultant Co@CNBs prepared at different temperatures (T = 600–1000 ˚C) are denoted as Co@CNB-T, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1 a, b and Fig. S5-S8, a bamboo-like structure has been observed. Slightly different morphologies of Co@CNBs-T were observed. TGA data (Fig. S9) shows that there are several key temperature nodes for the decomposition of Co-MONs, indicating that the formation of the Co@CNB is a complex process. The weight loss of Co-MONs below 360 °C was originated from the evaporation of adsorbed water/gases, and slight combustion of ligand species. The weight loss above 360 °C was ascribed to the further combustion of carbon, nitrogen and hydrogen species of the ligand with some surface-bonded oxygen-containing functional groups [50]. The formation of different morphologies of Co@CNBs-T is attributed to a different reaction process at different temperatures. During the experiment, we found that a segmented-heating process is favorable for the formation of Co@CNB with high quality (Fig. S10). This result suggests that the catalytic process between the gas and metal nanoparticles produced by decomposition at high temperatures is critical for the formation of the Co@CNBs structures. Compared with the Co-MONs, the Co@CNB-800 shows a BET surface area of 37.2 m2 g−1 with obvious mesopores. The Co@CNB became thicker compared to its Co-MON precursor. Moreover, there are nanoparticles encapsulated in the hollow carbon nanobamboos, with a size ranging from 20 to 40 nm (Fig. 1d). The detailed structures of Co@CNB were further analyzed by using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular darkfield scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), and high resolution TEM (HR-TEM) (Fig. 1c, d and Fig. S11). One can see that the Co MNPs are covered with a carbon shell (Fig. S11). Such structure is beneficial for preventing Co MNPs from dissolution and aggregation during electrocatalysis. The composition of Co@CNB was preliminary investigated with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental analysis, as shown in Fig. 1d. As expected, the C and N are distributed along the entire CNB skeleton, while the Co MNP is located inside the CNB. In accordance of the EDS results, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results also reveal that the Co@CNB is composed of C, N, Co and O (Fig. S12). The N contents of Co@CNB-T (T = 600, 700, 800, 900, 1000 ˚C) were determined to be 3.36%, 1.7%, 1.61%, 1.03% and 0.87%, respectively, with the XPS data. A decrease of nitrogen content was observed as temperature increased. XPS was also used to study the valence states of Co and N (Fig. 1f, g). A binding energy (BE) of 778.7 and 791.1 eV, which corresponding Co 2p 2/3 and Co 2p 1/2, can be noted from Fig. 1f, suggesting that Co dominantly existed in zero valency that is likely caused by the cover of inert carbon nanoshell. The XRD patterns of the Co@CNB-T also demonstrate the presence of Co MNPs, as their diffraction peaks matched well with reference positions from the JCPDS database (PCDF#15-0806). As presented in Fig. 1g, there are four deconvoluted peaks at BE of 398.5, 400.9, 402.5, and 406.4 eV, which are ascribed to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and oxidized N of the N 1s spectra, respectively. Recently, pyridinic N was conceived as the ORR active site with a pyridinic N-doped HOPG model catalysts [51]. The doping of pyridinic N of Co@CNB may lead to a change of the spin and atomic charge density, which optimizes the oxygen adsorption/desorption process, and thus enhances the ORR activity [31,32]. The ORR measurements were carried out in a three-electrode electrochemical system. All of the potentials have been converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) potential. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) technique was employed to gain insight into the electrochemical behaviors of the as-prepared catalyst loaded on rotating disk electrode (RDE). Since most of the practical alkaline ORR-related deveices are operating in strong basic condition, the CV scans were conducted in Ar- or O2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KOH with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1, as depicted in Fig. 2 a. A much larger reduction peak of Co@CNB-800 can be seen in O2-saturated electrolyte in comparison with that in Ar-saturated counterpart, suggesting much higher ORR activity; similar to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst (Fig. S13). The ORR performance of Co@CNB-800 was then evaluated with linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) technique at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 under different rotating speeds, as depicted in Fig. 2b. Co@CNB-800 exhibits an onset potential of 0.95 V and half-wave potential of 0.84 V for ORR, which are comparable to that of Pt/C (0.96 and 0.86 V for onset potential and half-wave potential, respectively). These values are also better than the reported Fe3C@NCNT/NPC [52], Co3S4–S/G-800[53] and others (Table S1). Furthermore, Co@CNB-800 also affords a larger limiting-diffusion current density than that of Pt/C (Fig. 2b, inset). For the cathode catalyst, its resistance towards methanol crossover is of paramount importance for the stable operation of fuel cell. In significant contrast to Pt/C, Co@CNB-800 showed a negligible current change upon the addition of methanol (Fig. S14). This observation clear indicates the excellent tolerance for methanol crossover of Co@CNB-800. The linear Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots (Fig. 2c) calculated at different potentials from the LSV curves in Fig. 2b suggests the first-order reaction kinetics for ORR in the electrolyte. The average electron-transfer number (n) for ORR of Co@CNBs-800 has been calculated to 3.96, which is close to that of Pt/C (n = 4.0, Fig. S13d), implying that the dissolved oxygen was dominantly reduced to water. The durability for different ORR catalysts was examined with an accelerated durability test (ADT) method, which reveals that Co@CNB-800 shows a smaller change of the half-wave potential and limiting-diffusion current density compared to that of Pt/C catalyst after 5000 cycles of CV scan in O2-saturated electrolyte (Fig. 2d and Fig. S13c). One can see that Co@CNB-800 has an excellent catalytic activity and stability toward ORR, which render it practical applications. The excellent ORR performances of Co@CNB-800 can be originated from the strong electronic coupling between bamboo-liked N-doped carbon nanotubes and encapsulated Co MNPs through their respective active sites. To screen the catalysts with best ORR performance, all of the other Co@CNBs have also been tested for ORR (Fig. S15-18, Table S1). The Co@CNBs prepared at different temperatures presented different ORR activity due to its tiny structural and compositional differences. All of these developed Co@CNBs are active for ORR with an electron-transfer number of nearly 4. Co@CNB-800 shows the best ORR performance among these catalysts in terms of the onset potential, half-wave potential and limiting-diffusion current density. The ORR performance of Co@CNBs in lower pH electrolyte was also examined. However, its stability was poorer than that in higher pH electrolyte due to the dissolution of Co nanoparticles in the lower pH electrolyte. Towards further understanding the electrocatalytic behavior of Co@CNB, DFT calculations were conducted focusing on Co@CNBs modelled with different curvatures of N-doped carbon wall and encapsulated Co nanoparticles (Co@CNB_h and Co@CNB_l, where h and l represent high and low curvatures, respectively), and a series of nanostructures (carbon nanotubes, N-doped carbon nanotubes and graphene, which denoted as CNT, NCNT and Gr, respectively), as well as the Pt(111) reference (Fig. S19). To investigate the preference between two reaction mechanisms and to estimate the catalytic activity trend over different catalysts, the linear correlations between the adsorption energies of different adsorbates (OH* and OOH*) with the descriptor (adsorption energy of O*) were established, namely the scaling relations (Fig. 3 a and 3b). Accordingly, the changing of reaction free energies of electrochemical steps at varying O* adsorption energies have been built at 0.8 V vs RHE (Fig. 3d, dotted lines). On the other hand, the activation barriers of thermochemical O2 dissociation were considered. Therefore, transition states of O2 dissociation over different catalysts were located and the activation barriers of O2 dissociation were also calculated as a function of the descriptor, where a linear correlation has been established (Fig. 3c). Hereafter, the activation barrier of O2 dissociation at varying O* adsorption (Fig. 3d, blue dash line) can be compared with the changing of reaction free energies for electrochemical steps. It is noted that many advanced schemes were developed to study the potential-dependent activation barriers [54–57], nevertheless, no additional barrier were considered for electrochemical steps in this work due to the negative reaction free energy mentioned in previous studies [47–49]. As a result, the associative mechanism was found to be more favored over the studied catalysts in this work, where the O2 dissociation was calculated to be always more difficult with higher barrier (Fig. 3d) than any of the electrochemical steps within the varying of descriptor (1.5 eV < GO* < 4.5 eV). Moreover, the activity trend can be predicted based on the changing of reaction free energies. The ΔG-limiting energies (Glim ) with relevant steps can be identified by the following expression at a given value of descriptor: G lim = m a x ( Δ G R 1 , Δ G R 2 , Δ G R 3 , Δ G R 4 ) The O* protonation was found to be the ΔG-limiting step with strong O* adsorption energies while the O2 protonation (Fig. 3d, black solid lines) will limit the entire activity with the weakening of O* adsorption energy (GO* > 2.02 eV). To further identify the catalytic activity for different catalysts, a two-dimensional (2D) activity map was established at the electrode potential of 0.8 V vs RHE (Fig. 3e) based on the linear relations, where the adsorption energies of OOH* was considered independently as a second descriptor towards a more accurate prediction of activity for specific electrode materials. First, the reaction mechanisms were also studied in the 2D activity map. The dissociative mechanism was found to be preferred with strong O* adsorption energies and weak OOH* adsorption energies (Fig. 3e, Path II) due to a more difficult O2 protonation with easier O2 dissociation. However, the associative mechanisms (Fig. 3e, Path I) was found to be more favored over all nanostructures studied in this work. With the explicit consideration of OOH* adsorption energies, a comparable activity with Pt can be achieved in Co@CNB. However, Co@CNB could outperform Pt considering the contribution of the curvature of carbon wall, as shown in Fig. 3e. A detailed comparison was displayed by the free energy diagram between Pt(111) and Co@CNB_l at 0 V and 0.8 V vs RHE (Fig. 3f). Though Pt(111) has better activity at low potential (<0.8 V vs RHE), its activity drops above 0.8 V vs RHE, as seen by the slight uphill O* protonation step. In contrast, the reaction energy remains negative for all electrochemical steps over Co@CNB_l. In this work, the pure nanotube structures (and pure graphene) were also studied to understand the effect from additional Co nanoparticles. Stronger bonding energies of all adsorbates in ORR were calculated with the addition of Co particles, which enhanced the catalytic activity based on the activity map (Fig. 3e). To further investigate the effect of Co nanoparticles, projected density of state (PDOS) was calculated for pure and Co coupled carbon nanostructures toward an investigation of chemical bonds in electronic level (Fig. 4 ). As a result, the electronic resonance was found to locate at a lower energy state, based on the overlap of PDOS between 2p orbitals for O and C, for Co-coupled carbon nanostructures compared with pure carbon nanostructures, which reveals that a stronger bonding can be expected with the addition of Co nanoparticles considering either low or high curvature of carbon wall. Moreover, the individual effects from either doped N or the addition of Co nanoparticles on adsorption energies were studied in this work. Strengthening of O* adsorption energy of 0.87, 1.03 and 1.38 eV was obtained for the encapsulation of Co nanoparticles, N doping, and both effects, respectively. It worth noting that DFT calculations show that lower ΔG-limiting energy can be obtained over Co@CNB_h than Pt, suggesting better activity than Pt can be achieved in Co@CNB depending on the curvature of carbon shell (Fig. 3e). Despite the challenges of realizing high curvature and high N doping concentration, it still indicates the great promise of the material of Co@CNB for achieving unprecedented ORR activity. To further demonstrate possible application of Co@CNB in practical ORR-related devices, a home-made Zn-air battery (ZAB) was fabricated. Co@CNB-800 has been employed as the air cathode catalyst, and its performances were compared with those of Pt/C. The initial open circuit voltage (OCV) of the ZAB with Co@CNB-800 is about 1.47 V, as displayed in the inset of Fig. 5 a; and its OCV is slightly higher than the ZAB with Pt/C. The peak power density of the ZAB with Co@CNB-800 is 113 mW cm−2, which is higher than the ZAB with noble-metal Pt/C of 98 mW cm−2 (Fig. 5b). This value is also better than the reported catalysts for ZAB, such as N-GCNT/FeCo-3[58], Fe-Nx-C [59] and ZAB with MnO2/NRGO-Urea catalyst and PAM-based AGE [60]. The cycling stability of ZAB with the as-made catalyst and Pt/C were also tested, with a constant current density of 5 mA cm−2. The corresponding cycling discharging/charging curves are presented in Fig. 5c. The change in discharging/charging voltage gap (ΔEgap change = 0.32 V) for the ZAB with Co@CNB-800 is smaller than that with Pt/C (ΔEgap change = 0.78 V) after 300 cycles (Fig. 5d), indicating a much better cycling stability. These results suggest the feasibility of the developed Co@CNB catalyst as the cathode materials for practical and reliable ORR-related batteries. 4 Conclusion In summary, one-dimensional Co-MONs has been prepared, for the first time, by using the TA as the organic linker. Carbonization of these NWs leads to the formation of Co@CNB, i.e., Co nanoparticles encapsulated in carbon nanobamboos. The as-prepared Co@CNB-800 shows remarkable ORR performance, which affords an onset potential and half-wave potential of 0.95 and 0.84 V, respectively. DFT calculations suggest that the Co nanoparticles encapsulation can strengthen the bonding energies of adsorbates on the carbon wall, compared with that on pure carbon nanostructures. With sufficiently high curvature of carbon shell, Co@CNB could have higher intrinsic ORR activity than Pt. As a proof-of-concept, the Co@CNB is used in a ZAB as the cathode catalyst. The ZAB with Co@CNB shows a peak power density of 113 mW cm−2, which is higher than that of ZAB with Pt/C (98 mW cm−2). The ZAB with Co@CNB shows a change of discharging/charging voltage gap of 0.32 V after 300 cycles, much lower than that (0.78 V) of ZAB with Pt/C measured under the same conditions; indicating a much better cycling stability. The developed materials show great potential as an alternative to commercial Pt/C catalysts for ORR, and thus could have wide practical application in ORR-related metal-air batteries. coredata.dc:description: One-dimensional (1D) metal-organic nanostructures hold great promise for preparing various 1D carbon/metal derivatives toward various electrocatalysis including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR); but it is challenging to synthesize them. Herein, 1D cobalt(Co)-metal-organic nanowires are prepared using the complex of Co2+ and 1, 2, 4-triazole. Direct carbonization of the as-prepared nanowires affords a well-defined structure of Co nanoparticles encapsulated inside the bamboo-liked 1D carbon nanostructure, i.e., carbon nanobamboos (Co@CNB). Owing to the outstanding electronic transport in bamboo-liked carbon structure, strong electronic coupling between the N-doped carbon and Co nanoparticles, the Co@CNB catalyst exhibits an excellent ORR performance comparable to the commercial Pt/C in alkaline solution. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the Co@CNB can strengthen the adsorption of all adsorbates (O*, OH* and OOH*) compared with a carbon nanotube, benifical for oxygen protonation and thus enhancing the ORR activity. Moreover, it is possible to outperform Pt intrinsically if the curvature of carbon shell is high enough in Co@CNB. Lastly, the zinc-air battery (ZAB) fabricated with Co@CNB as the cathode catalyst shows a higher peak power density and better cycling durability than those of the ZAB with Pt/C; suggesting the great potential of Co@CNB as efficient electrocatalysts for metal-air batteries.
coredata.dc:title: One-dimensional metal-organic nanowires-derived catalyst of carbon nanobamboos with encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles for oxygen reduction
